entry.title: Invoking LLM from Cloud Integration Responsibly ‚Äì Made Easy with Generative AI Hub in SAP AI Core
entry.content:
In this blog post, I‚Äôll walk you through how to seamlessly invoke large language models (LLMs) from Cloud Integration using the Generative AI Hub and the Orchestration Workflow API in SAP AI Core. We‚Äôll focus on building a GDPR-compliant automation flow that leverages data masking and pseudonymisation to ensure privacy while still delivering value from generative AI.

The scenario we'll explore simulates a real-world use case: when a Business Partner record is updated in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, a personalized email notification is generated by an LLM and automatically sent out via Cloud Integration.

Thanks to prebuilt orchestration capabilities of Generative AI Hub in SAP AI Core, such as templating, I/O filtering, and data masking, the process of generating compliant LLM responses can be achieved with just a single API call.

‚ÄÉ

Before diving into the implementation steps, let‚Äôs take a closer look at the process flow behind this sample scenario.

Process Flow (Steps)

  1. Business Partner Update in SAP S/4HANA Cloud
    A user creates or edits a Business Partner record in SAP S/4HANA Cloud.
  2. Event Triggered and Message Sent to SAP AEM
    The system triggers an event and sends a message to SAP Advanced Event Mesh (AEM).
  3. Cloud Integration iFlow Subscribes and Starts Processing
    The CPI iFlow subscribes to the AEM queue and begins processing as soon as a new message is published.
  4. Retrieve Old Payload from CAP Application
    The iFlow queries the CAP application to retrieve the previous version (old payload) of the Business Partner record from SAP HANA Cloud.
  5. Call the Orchestration Workflow API of SAP AI Core for AI-Based Email Generation
    With both the old and new payloads in hand, the iFlow invokes the Generative AI Hub using the Orchestration Workflow API of SAP AI Core to generate a personalized email body in HTML format. Here, a predefined orchestration pipeline applies data masking, prompt templating, and foundation model invocation to generate a compliant, personalised email body ‚Äì without exposing any sensitive data.
  6. Send Email to Business Partner
    The iFlow sends the generated email to the Business Partner‚Äôs email address via a standard mail adapter in Cloud Integration, completing the end-to-end notification process.

As part of this blog, I will not focus on connectivity between SAP S/4HANA Cloud and SAP Advanced Event Mesh (steps 1 and 2). For a live step-by-step demonstration of the setup, please review this video: üëâ SAP Tech Bytes: Configuring SAP S/4HANA Cloud and SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh

Configuring Orchestration Workflow in SAP AI Core

Orchestration in SAP AI Core is a managed service that enables unified access, control, and execution of generative AI models through standardized APIs, templating, and configurable AI workflow components.

In our scenario, we will utilize it to chain together prebuilt steps, such as data masking and foundation model invocation, to generate a personalized email body in HTML format via a single API call.

To access the Orchestration service in SAP AI Core, you need to set up Generative AI Hub in SAP AI Core and SAP AI Launchpad. Please refer to either of the following resources for setup instructions:

  • SAP Discovery Mission: Set Up SAP AI Core Generative AI Hub
  • SAP Developer Center Tutorial: Generative AI with SAP AI Core - Setup

Before moving to the next step, please ensure that your orchestration configuration is deployed and is in the RUNNING status.

Building the Orchestration Workflow

Within SAP AI Launchpad, navigate to Generative AI Hub -> Orchestration and click Edit Workflow to select the workflow steps you require.

For our scenario, deselect the Input Translation and Output Translation steps, as they are not needed.

In the Templating step, we define prompts that guide LLM on how to perform its task.

We configure two types of messages for our scenario:

  • System Prompt
  • User Prompt

The system prompt defines the overall behavior, tone, and role of the LLM. It sets global instructions that remain consistent across requests, ensuring predictable formatting and response style.

For our use case, the system prompt will instruct the LLM to act as a multilingual assistant that compares old and new Business Partner profiles and generates a compliant email.

You are a multilingual assistant. Your task is to compare the old and new payloads of a Business Partner profile and generate a personalized, polite, and human-sounding email to inform the Business Partner about the changes made to their profile. If no changes are found, reply "NO_CHANGES".
Instructions:
- Detect all relevant changes (ignore changes in fields named change_time or change_date).
- Summarize the changes clearly and concisely.
- Keep it concise and clear.
- Format the response as HTML (do not use code blocks).
- Use paragraphs (<p>) for separate blocks of text.
- Use an unordered list (<ul>) with list items (<li>) to list the changes.
- Address the Business Partner by full name if available.
- End the email with the following closing, exactly as shown: Best regards,<br>SAP BTP Adoption & Consumption Center.
- Keep the tone friendly, clear, and professional.
- Do not generate the email subject line, only the body.

The user prompt provides the dynamic, task-specific input for each request. Here, we pass actual data: the old profile payload, new profile payload, and target language. These placeholders will be replaced at runtime to generate personalized content.

Write the email in the language: {{?language_name}}
Here is the OLD profile payload: {{?old_payload}}
Here is the NEW profile payload: {{?new_payload}}

 

In the Data Masking step, we can anonymize or pseudonymize personally identifiable information from the input for selected entities. For our scenario, we will select the Pseudonymization option. This will substitute personally identifiable information in selected categories with a MASKED_ENTITY_ID placeholder and allow us to unmask the LLM response before returning it to the Sender.

The Input Filtering step allows you to apply content safety filters to the incoming data before invoking the foundation model.

In the Model Configuration step, we can select the desired model (e.g., GPT-4.1) and configure relevant parameters such as temperature, token limits, etc.

Finally, the Output Filtering step enables content safety filtering on the LLM-generated response to ensure compliance and prevent undesired content.

Once the orchestration workflow is configured, you can inspect its JSON definition and download it locally. This definition will be used later when invoking the orchestration workflow via API from Cloud Integration.

Additionally, you can test the orchestration inference directly within SAP AI Launchpad by providing sample input variables. The testing tool allows you to view and trace the LLM response and fine-tune the workflow configuration as needed.

When inspecting the output payload, you can clearly trace the results of each orchestration step ‚Äì such as Input Masking, Output Unmasking, Input Filtering, and Output Filtering.

To learn more about Orchestration in SAP AI Core, refer to the SAP Developer Center Tutorials: Generative AI with SAP AI Core - orchestration.

Configure SAP Cloud Integration Business Partner Notification iFlow

Now that we have our SAP S/4HANA Cloud, SAP Advanced Event Mesh, and the Orchestration Workflow in SAP AI Core configured, we can proceed with the Cloud Integration iFlow configuration.

This iFlow ensures that Business Partner changes trigger compliant AI-generated email notifications, while maintaining data consistency in HANA Cloud. It leverages SAP Advanced Event Mesh, CAP, and Generative AI Hub for an automated end-to-end process.

High-Level iFlow Overview

  • Triggered by AEM Queue when a new event is published.
  • Retrieves BP details from S/4HANA Cloud.
  • (If event is BP update) Fetches old BP payload from HANA Cloud (via CAP service).
  • Invokes the Orchestration Workflow API to compare old vs. new payloads and generate an HTML email content while ensuring that no sensitive information is passed to LLM.
  • Upserts updated BP details into SAP HANA Cloud via CAP service.
  • Sends an email to the Business Partner.

Step-by-Step Process Breakdown

  1. Event Trigger
    • The iFlow subscribes to the AEM queue and processes incoming events.
  2. Retrieve Business Partner Details
    • An OData request is sent to SAP S/4HANA Cloud to fetch the latest BP details.
    • Key parameters (e.g., BP ID, BP email) are extracted and saved into the properties for further processing.
  3. Map to CAP Format
    • BP details are transformed into the CAP service data model.
    • The new payload is stored in XML and JSON format for further use.
  4. Conditional Logic
    • BP creation ‚Üí No old payload is retrieved.
    • BP update ‚Üí Old payload is retrieved for comparison.
  5. Retrieve Old Payload from HANA Cloud (BP update only)
    • The iFlow calls the CAP service to fetch the previous BP record. Please refer to the GitHub repository businesspartner_srv for more information on the CAP service. In our scenario, the CAP service acts as an intermediary that retrieves old Business Partner data from SAP HANA Cloud, provides an OData service for data access, and enables the upsert of updated details.
  6. AI-Based Email Generation
    • A subprocess calls the Orchestration Workflow API via the AI adapter to create a personalized HTML email body in a GDPR-compliant way.
  7. Upsert BP Details in HANA Cloud
    • The updated BP details are upserted into SAP HANA Cloud via the CAP service.
  8. Send Email
    • The iFlow sends an email using the Mail Adapter.

You can find this iFlow as a ZIP archive here: AEM_GenAI_BPMailGenerator_blog.zip

For this blog, we‚Äôll take a closer look at Step #6, where the AI Receiver Adapter is used to invoke the Orchestration Workflow API configured in the previous section.

1) In our case, the easiest way to prepare a payload for the AI Receiver Adapter is by using a small Groovy script.

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message
import groovy.json.JsonOutput

Message processData(Message message) {
    def map = message.getProperties()

    // Get values from properties
    def language = map.get("language")
    def oldPayload = map.get("old_payload_json")
    def newPayload = map.get("new_payload_json")

    // Build the JSON structure
    def payload = [
        orchestration_config: [
            module_configurations: [
                llm_module_config: [
                    model_name: "gpt-4.1",
                    model_params: [
                        frequency_penalty: 0,
                        presence_penalty: 0,
                        max_completion_tokens: 24576,
                        temperature: 1
                    ],
                    model_version: "2025-04-14"
                ],
                templating_module_config: [
                    template: [
                        [
                            role: "user",
                            content: [
                                [
                                    type : "text",
                                    text : "Write the email in the language: {{?language_name}}\nHere is the OLD profile payload: {{?old_payload}}\nHere is the NEW profile payload: {{?new_payload}}"
                                ]
                            ]
                        ],
                        [
                            role: "system",
                            content: [
                                [
                                    type : "text",
                                    text : """You are a multilingual assistant. Your task is to compare the old and new payloads of a Business Partner profile and generate a personalized, polite, and human-sounding email to inform the Business Partner about the changes made to their profile. If no changes are found, reply "NO_CHANGES".

Instructions:
- Detect all changes.
- Summarize them clearly.
- Keep it concise and clear.
- Don't generate the subject, only the email body.
- Format it as an HTML (NO code blocks like ```html).
- Ignore change_time change_date changes.
- Address the Business Partner by full name if available.
- Include a friendly closing.
- End the email with the following closing, exactly as shown: Best regards,<br>SAP BTP Adoption & Consumption Center."""
                                ]
                            ]
                        ]
                    ],
                    defaults: [:]
                ],
                filtering_module_config: [
                input : [
                    filters: [
                        [
                            type: "azure_content_safety",
                            config: [
                                Hate: 2,
                                SelfHarm: 2,
                                Sexual: 2,
                                Violence: 2,
                                PromptShield: true
                            ]
                        ]
                    ]
                ],
                output: [
                    filters: [
                        [
                            type  : "azure_content_safety",
                            config: [
                                Hate: 2,
                                SelfHarm: 2,
                                Sexual: 2,
                                Violence: 2
                            ]
                        ]
                    ]
                ]
            ],
                masking_module_config: [
                    masking_providers: [
                        [
                            type: "sap_data_privacy_integration",
                            method: "pseudonymization",
                            entities: [
                                [type: "profile-credit-card-number"],
                                [type: "profile-driverlicense"],
                                [type: "profile-email"],
                                [type: "profile-sensitive-data"],
                                [type: "profile-ethnicity"],
                                [type: "profile-gender"],
                                [type: "profile-pronouns-gender"],
                                [type: "profile-iban"],
                                [type: "profile-location"],
                                [type: "profile-nationalid"],
                                [type: "profile-nationality"],
                                [type: "profile-org"],
                                [type: "profile-passport"],
                                [type: "profile-person"],
                                [type: "profile-phone"],
                                [type: "profile-political-group"],
                                [type: "profile-sapids-public"],
                                [type: "profile-religious-group"],
                                [type: "profile-sapids-internal"],
                                [type: "profile-ssn"],
                                [type: "profile-sexual-orientation"],
                                [type: "profile-trade-union"],
                                [type: "profile-address"],
                                [type: "profile-url"],
                                [type: "profile-university"],
                                [type: "profile-username-password"]
                            ],
                            mask_grounding_input: [enabled: false],
                            allowlist: []
                        ]
                    ]
                ]
            ]
        ],
        input_params: [
            language_name: language,
            old_payload: oldPayload instanceof String ? oldPayload : JsonOutput.toJson(oldPayload),
            new_payload: newPayload instanceof String ? newPayload : JsonOutput.toJson(newPayload)
        ]
    ]

    // Serialize to JSON string
    def jsonString = JsonOutput.toJson(payload)
    message.setBody(jsonString)

    return message
}
‚Äã

This script constructs the payload expected by the Orchestration API of SAP AI Core.

Note that the settings within the module_configurations block match the configuration that you downloaded from SAP AI Launchpad.

2) To set up a Connection to our AI Core Orchestration deployment, we first need to configure a Security Material.
In your SAP BTP Cockpit and access the service key of the SAP AI Core (extended plan) service instance created earlier.

Create an OAuth2 Client Credentials Security Material with:

  • Token Service URL: url from the service key + ‚Äú/oauth/token‚Äù
  • Client ID: clientid from the service key
  • Client Secret: clientsecret from the service key

On the Connection tab of the AI Receiver Adapter:

  • Set the Address to the AI_API_URL from the service key.
  • Reference the Security Material in the OAuth2 Client Credentials field.

On the Processing tab:

  • Set Request Payload Source to ‚ÄúExchange Body‚Äù.
  • Provide the Orchestration Deployment ID and AI Resource Group from SAP AI Launchpad.

3) JSON output is converted into XML for further processing.

4) Content Modifier step is used to extract the email_body from the Orchestration API response via the XPath expression: /root/orchestration_result/choices/message/content

Testing the Scenario End-to-End

With all components configured, it‚Äôs time to put the setup to the test.

üìΩÔ∏è Watch Event-Driven Business Partner Email Notification Demo 

The video walks through the entire process ‚Äì showing the change in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, the processing inside Cloud Integration, and the final email received by the Business Partner.

Conclusion

This scenario highlights how simple and seamless it is to invoke SAP AI Core from Cloud Integration to generate compliant, human-sounding content.

With just a small Groovy script to prepare the payload, CPI can call an SAP AI Core Orchestration Workflow directly via the AI Receiver Adapter ‚Äì without complex custom coding or middleware. All compliance safeguards, such as data masking and filtering, are handled by the orchestration workflow, ensuring that no sensitive information is ever sent to the LLM.

The result is an automated, end-to-end process where a Business Partner update in SAP S/4HANA Cloud triggers an event, CPI processes it, SAP AI Core generates the compliant email body, and the recipient is informed ‚Äì all with minimal configuration effort.

This pattern can be applied to other master data objects and backend systems, as well as to any scenario where Cloud Integration must securely generate AI-based content ‚Äî making it a powerful blueprint for scaling compliant AI adoption across the enterprise.

entry.title: Re: Change EKET - EINDT as a collectively
entry.content:
The standard approach would be to use Transaction ME38 from where you can mass update delivery dates for multiple items. Navigate to the schedule lines and change EINDT directly.

If you're working with purchase orders, go to ME22N, use the ‚ÄúCollective Processing‚Äù or ‚ÄúMass Change‚Äù options. Select multiple items and update the delivery date (EINDT) in one go.

If standard transactions don‚Äôt meet your needs, you can use BAPI_PO_CHANGE: For purchase orders

Finally and most importantly, SAP may override EINDT values based on delivery schedules, MRP, or vendor confirmations. So test thoroughly in QA system before applying in production.

entry.title: Re: DI API Problem Class COM with SAP Business One Applic...
entry.content:
I just noticed that the article is in French and it is not possible to copy the text, so I leave you the solution here in English

 

Diagnostic:

‚ö†Ô∏è This behavior is known ‚Äî Technical explanation
The DI API (COM) registers through CLSIDs in the Windows registry.
When both versions (32-bit and 64-bit) are installed, Windows may point the COM class to the wrong version because:

  • The COM registry (HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\CLSID) does not always correctly differentiate between 32-bit and 64-bit.

  • Some GUIDs may be overwritten or shared between the two versions.
    This is a COM registration conflict issue between the two architectures.

Recommended Solution: Isolate or Force the COM Architecture Used

 Avoid COM Registration Conflicts

a. Use a tool like RegSvr32 with the /regserver option to manually re-register the 64-bit DI API after installing the 32-bit version.

 
C:\Windows\System32\regsvr32.exe "C:\Program Files\SAP\SAP Business One DI API\SAPbobsCOM.dll"

This forces the 64-bit COM registration, even if the 32-bit version is also installed.

You can also run the following in CMD:

 
C:\Windows\SysWOW64\regsvr32.exe "C:\Program Files (x86)\SAP\SAP Business One DI API\DI API xx\SAPbobsCOMxx.dll"

(Here, xx represents the version number of the file ‚Äî this is for re-registering the 32-bit version.)

Important:
Always ensure the correct version is registered for the application in use.

entry.title: Re: STMS configuration with ctc=1: SNOTE transports
entry.content:
Hello Gergo,
Thank you for your reply.
Yes, most SAP notes are client-independent, but it would be cleaner if the transport layers were unique.
We usually generate transports from the PFCG, but in some cases, roles are also assigned to the transport as objects via lists. For transport layers, the transport system checks the correctness of the transport routes, so it would be nice to be able to define name-specific rules for this.
I would like to eliminate sources of error as far as possible.
Best regards,
Andreas

entry.title: Key Technical Updates for SAP Commerce Cloud
entry.content:
The SAP Commerce Cloud 2211 continuous innovation release model offers substantial benefits to our customers by ensuring faster access to the latest features, enhancements, and security updates. This approach allows for seamless and frequent updates, minimizing disruptions while maintaining a robust and high-performing e-commerce platform. Our customers can take advantage of new innovations quickly, stay ahead of market demands, and maintain competitive agility, all while reducing the risk associated with traditional major version cycles.

Consider the following key aspects when working with SAP technology: 

  • Stay current with SAP Commerce Cloud Release Updates
  • Review all features, services, and updates (Solr, Composable Storefront)

#1 ‚Äì Stay Current with SAP Commerce Cloud Release Updates

Staying up-to-date with SAP Commerce Cloud 2211 and Composable Storefront guarantees that our customers will remain current on the latest enhancements, software updates and bug fixes. 

To assist our customers to prepare for upcoming changes and implementations, SAP publishes the Notification of Key Technical Updates on the SAP Help Portal.  

This continuously updated documentation highlights when changes are available, including features and services that offer an adoption window. SAP is committed to support your planning, so we encourage you to bookmark this page and check it frequently to stay current with the latest updates.

Important: The following is a list of key updates to consider in the upcoming quarter, with the Framework Update having the highest impact on your planning. Be sure to read through the information provided carefully.

Top considerations for the upcoming quarter:

  • Framework Update (JDK 21, Spring 6)
    Dependencies to Framework Update
    • OAuth replacement
    • Drools Update

Deprecation of Extensions:

Be aware that SAP has removed several extensions from Commerce Cloud and from Integration Extension Pack due to incompatibilities with the newest versions of Java and/or Spring. Replacement solutions already exist for each use case and are documented on the SAP Help Portal. These deprecated extensions are highlighted on the Key Technical Updates help page. Use the "Production Version" filter for September 2025 for a complete overview.

  • See the Deletion of Deprecated Cockpit Extensions
  • See the Deletion of Deprecated amazoncloud Extension
  • See the Deletion of Deprecated Sales Order Simulation Extensions
  • See the Deletion of Deprecated Customer Order Sourcing Extensions
  • See the Deletion of Synchronous Order Management as well as the SAP For Me Note

Additionally, for more information about the suggested solution, SmartEdit, for the CSM Cockpit deprecation:

  • Getting Started with SmartEdit 
  • SmartEdit Feature Parity
  • Technical Overview of SmartEdit

Understand the Framework Update impact for your SAP Commerce Cloud implementation by leveraging the Preview release. Preview releases allow you to evaluate and explore the changes before they are available in production in the September 2025 update release. The previews are meant for non-productive use, so you can implement them in development, sandbox, or staging environments.

For more information, refer to the following documentation:

  • Framework Update ‚Äì Detailed Overview
  • SAP Commerce Cloud Release Ready Kit
  • Preview of the September Update Release
  • List of supported SAP Commerce Cloud releases

For Composable Storefront:

New releases of Composable Storefront are fully tested and support the current 2211 backend releases. Use of Composable Storefront with older backends is not supported. Review the list of supported Composable Storefront releases below to ensure that you are on a storefront version that is supported and running smoothly.

Additionally, building Composable Storefront and SSR hosting is only supported with the latest supported versions of Node.js, provided by the Cloud Portal. 

For more information, refer to the following documentation:

  • List of supported Composable Storefront releases; includes supported backends
  • Angular and Node.js dependencies matrix

#2 - Review all components

The ecosystem surrounding an SAP Commerce Cloud installation includes many components. You must maintan these components to stay compatible in alignment with the SAP Commerce Cloud releases. SAP has made significant efforts to align the releases of components, such as Composable Storefront.

An important component of Commerce Cloud is Solr, plan your activities according to the following Solr Version Validity Policy and make sure you update your installation of Solr before the expiration date.

For more information, refer to the following documentation:

  • Minor Solr Version Validity
  • Upgrading to Solr 9.x

If you want to remove this dependency and adopt new search and AI innovations immediately with auto-upgrades, consider migrating to the Search Service and sign-up to the Early Adopter Care Program.

For more information:

  • To receive important notifications about your Commerce Cloud subscription, visit the SAP Support portal and subscribe to the SAP Cloud System Notification Subscription (CSNS) service.
  • For instructions on enabling new features and functionality, see:
    o Enabling SAP Commerce Cloud in the Upgrading SAP Commerce Cloud guide
    o Feature Flags in the Composable Storefront documentation

For details about what‚Äôs available now and what you can expect in upcoming releases, see:

  • For Commerce Cloud 2211:
       o About SAP Commerce Cloud Release 2211
       o What‚Äôs New in SAP Commerce Cloud
       o SAP Commerce Cloud Product Road Map
       o Notification of Key Technical Updates
  • For Composable Storefront:
       o About Composable Storefront
       o What‚Äôs New in Composable Storefront
       o SAP Commerce Cloud Product Road Map

For any questions, don‚Äôt hesitate to contact your account team.

entry.title: Re: Integration Suite and Connection Type G for synchrono...
entry.content:
Hello @CodeMadeInGermany 

SAP Integration Suite (Cloud Integration) can call synchronous BAPIs, but not using connection type G. In ABAP, type G is an HTTP destination, so SE37 does not use it for RFC/BAPI calls. For synchronous BAPIs, an RFC connection (ABAP type) is required, along with the RFC receiver adapter in Integration Suite (via SAP Cloud Connector) to handle sRFC calls and send responses back to your iFlow. A common passthrough iFlow setup includes an HTTPS sender ‚Üí RFC receiver adapter (sRFC); only map necessary data and let the adapter handle commit/rollback options needed. SAP Help PortalSAP Business Accelerator Hub

If you want to expose the function via HTTP instead, you can wrap the BAPI as a SOAP or Odata service in the ABAP system and then call it from CPI using HTTP/SOAP. This is when an SM59 type G destination becomes relevant, though you‚Äôre no longer making an RFC call. Also, note that RFC sender to CPI isn‚Äôt supported yet, so for calls from ABAP to CPI, use IDoc, SOAP, or proxies instead.

With kind regards

Chuma

https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-integration/sap-cloud-integration/rfc-receiver-adapter

Call a BAPI/RFC Module

entry.title: cTMS Setup for CAP Applications
entry.content:
cTMS Architecture ‚Äì CAP Apps

Here we have four environments Dev, QA, UAT, and Prod each corresponding to a separate BTP subaccount. We have provisioned the Cloud Transport Management Service (cTMS) in a separate subaccount. The development team builds custom CAP applications using Business Application Studio (BAS) and deploys them to the Dev environment via a Azure CI/CD pipeline. So please note that, this not using SAP's CI/CD pipeline. Simultaneously, the generated MTAR file is uploaded as a transport package to the QA node using cTMS. From there, it is imported into QA and the subsequent environments (UAT, Prod) through Solution Manager (SolMan), leveraging Focused Build (FB) or Charm status transitions.

Additionally, this setup can be integrated with SAP Cloud ALM.

Setup Steps:

Since several of these SaaS applications share common setup steps, please begin by following the initial setup steps outlined here Setting Up Cloud TMS for Various SAP SaaS Solutions 

Step1: Create Destinations to CF Subaccounts

In the subaccount where the Cloud Transport Management (cTMS) service is subscribed, create a destination to each target BTP subaccount. No destination setup for Dev node, as it's dummy node. 

Name: Give appropriate name to resemble your CTMS Node

URL: https://deploy-service.cf.<domain>/slprot/<myorg>/<myspace>/slp

Note: If you have multiple space setup in your BTP, you will have to setup cTMS for those spaces separately. 

Authentication: OAuth2Password.

Note: This requires a valid username and password. It is recommended to set up a technical user in your IAS for this purpose. Ensure that the password for this user never expires to avoid disruptions in connectivity. You should setup the user with Custom password policy where the password never expires. Also this user requires a space developer role in BTP. 

Client id: cf

Secret: should be left empty

Token Service URL: https://login.cf.<domain>

Additional property:

Origin: This field is required and must be configured with the appropriate value when using a user from IAS. It should match the origin key defined for your IAS tenant. This can be found in IAS trust configuration in BTP subaccount. 

Step2: Configure Transport Nodes in cTMS

Prerequisites

  • You have been assigned one of the following roles: Administrator or LandscapeOperator.

From the cTMS UI, you can define transport nodes to represent your system landscape. There are multiple ways to create a node:

You can either Create a node on the Landscape Visualization screen or from Transport Nodes screen. 

Note:
For CAP application scenario, the Development node is setup as a dummy (virtual) node, as no transports are exported or deployed from Dev and they are directly handed over from CI/CD pipeline to CAP QA Node. 

Allow Upload to Node: Enable this checkbox to allow file uploads to the node. Usually enabled for the Dev node. But for CAP Apps scenario, the Dev node is a dummy node (no upload), and QA is the node where uploads are allowed. So select this for QA node. 

Forward Mode: Default value is Auto, You can change this setting based on your landscape and transport flow requirements.

Controlled by SAP Solution Manager: Select this checkbox only if you plan to integrate with SAP Solution Manager (e.g., Charm or Focused Build). For CAP scenario, we will only enable this for UAT & Prod, as the transports are uploaded to QA Node.  When you enable this, it will not allow manual imports from cTMS UI, only through Charm/FB status change. 

Note: If you plan to integrate with Cloud ALM, do not check this option. 

Content Type: For CAP applications, select Multitarget Application (MTA).

Destination: Select the appropriate target destination you previously configured in your cTMS subaccount in Step1.

Step3: Create Transport routes in cTMS

In SAP Cloud Transport Management, transport routes are used to connect transport nodes.

Name: Provide the appropriate name

Chose the Source node & Target node and click on OK. 

After setting up Transport Nodes & routes, your landscape looks something like this based on the number of environments you have. 

Note: You can also use Transport Landscape Wizard, with which you can setup the all your landscape nodes & routes at a time.

Step4: Azure Pipeline Setup to integrate with cTMS

This diagram explain the CI/CD pipeline flow for custom application development and deployment. Work with your Development Team to update your Azure pipeline.yaml file with code something like below to handover transports to QA node as part of deploying them to Dev. There could be additional configuration. 

Step5: Integrate with Solution Manager/Cloud ALM

To integrate Cloud Transport Management (cTMS) with SAP Solution Manager (Charm / Focused Build), follow the step6 from below article. 

If you want to integrate with Cloud ALM, follow the step7 from below article. 

 Setting Up Cloud TMS for Various SAP SaaS Solutions 

Conclusion:

I hope you have learned, how to setup cTMS for Custom Applications developed based on CAP, especially with Azure pipeline. Now the setup is complete and ready for transporting content using cTMS either integrated with SAP Solution Manager or Cloud ALM. 

Thank you for reading my article, feel free to provide any feedback or comment for any questions.

Thanks,
Raghu

entry.title: Re: Datasphere replication flow Initial load in progress...
entry.content:
Hi @Arvind_Sharma1 ,

We also had the same issue recently with one of the replication flow. SAP provided some insights on the issue and action points to resolve it. After implementing these, all the replication flows are working fine. 

1. Maintain SAP_DHCDC_DISPATCHER, SAP_DHCDC_HOUSEKEEPER scope in STJR_JOBD_SCOPE table :  Both of the jobs mentioned are mandatory in ABAP / Datasphere integration scenario . We did this but still the issue was not resolved.

2. Technical user is not authorized to stop recording changes for subscriber RMS. : Please check if your technical user has the required access. We provided the authorization and the initial data started flowing. However, the RF failed after completing 90% of initial load. 

3. Increase TRANSFER_MAX_JOBS parameter of /1DH/PUSH_CDS_DELTA job from 1 to 4. : After implementing this change, all the replication flows started working. 

Hope this will be helpful in resolving the issue.

entry.title: Re: STMS configuration with ctc=1: SNOTE transports
entry.content:
Hi Andreas,

 

As explained at Transport Layers and Routes, objects delivered by SAP belong to the transport layer SAP.  You must already have a layer defined in the STMS route editor with such name (and the layer SAP assigned to a consolidation transport route), otherwise you wouldn't be able to transport any Note to further systems. So this is already unique. Customer layers' name should start with Z. This is how STMS and the transport organizer differentiates.

About the specific role transport issue/question, that should be answered by BC-SEC-AUT-PFC, who supports role transports from PFCG. If you don't get an answer from the community here, I suggest opening an expert chat on that component in SAP for ME.

 

Best regards,

Gergo

entry.title: Re: partially committed webservice-transactions in SQL An...
entry.content:
I can't tell what happens within a web procedure when the web client does not wait for the full response, and apparently the web server has no control over this.

As to "partial transactions". There's no such thing in a RDBMS. A transaction either commits or is rolled back, there is no middle ground. (We are not dealing with "nested transactions" aka savepoints, with those, you can roll back savepoints but commit the whole transaction.)

I guess the underlying problem is the behaviour of temporary tables with the NOT TRANSACTIONAL clause: Those do explicitely not follow transactional rules and are not bound to transaction scopes, so the INSERT may take place without an additional UPDATE - and without being rolled back by a rollback statement .

I even noticed that LOAD TABLE into a temporary tables with the NOT TRANSACTIONAL may insert some rows and stop when further rows would lead to errors, so in that context a single LOAD TABLE statement might be not even atomic. I'd asked for that a while ago - but won't take the effort to search this within this sub-optimal platform. üòï

To add: I guess I remember that a web service procedure stops the execution once the final SELECT statement is executed, so following statements will not be executed. This is probably something that Mark Culp has explained in detail.

In your case this would be an non-issue as the SELECT is the final statement, so just as a possible helpful hint. (I would probably had put the check for successful execution naively after the SELECT, and that might get lost then...)

entry.title: EBRR Currency Conversion with Spot Rate in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
Co-Authored by Stefan Walz and  Gabi Hoffmann

Welcome to this blog, in which we will show the new currency conversion in Event-Based Revenue Recognition. The new revenue recognition method will use a spot rate approach for EBRR postings instead of using a fixed exchange rate. In addition to these enhancements, we offer supplementary options for plan sources. The screenshots are taken from an SAP S/4HANA Cloud CE2508 system; the described functionality is only available in public cloud.

This functionality is based on the professional service tailored customer project scenario using fixed price billing with a cost-based POC.

We will start in this blog with a functional overview. Then we will show an end-to end process in the system based on the professional service tailored customer project scenario. We will close with insights into the EBRR configuration.

 

1.    Motivation and functional scope 

With release 2508, we have delivered a new revenue recognition method, with which the currency conversion is carried out using the rate of the period in which the confirmation/revenue realization takes place.

The method is particularly relevant when the exchange rate continuously and significantly changes in one direction during the project duration. In addition, we support with this method IFRS and US GAAP requirements.

Compared to the existing revenue recognition key SPFC, the new method involves a significantly more complex value determination. This additional complexity can increase the effort required to trace and understand the resulting accounting entries.

The currency conversion method linked to the default key SPFC ‚Äî which continues to use the frozen exchange rate from the time the billing WBS element was created ‚Äî remains fully supported.

Before switching to the new key, we recommend carefully evaluating the benefits and drawbacks of both approaches. While the new method may offer advantages in cases of significant, directional exchange rate fluctuations, it also introduces additional complexity that should be considered when assessing transparency and operational effort.

Motivation for the new EBRR currency method

To get an idea, how the old and new key/method work, we will look at an example. For that we assume a situation where the Euro continuously loses value against the GBP.

The table below shows a comparison of the different keys over a timeframe of 5 months. The project is set up with a project currency in GBP, with a GB customer, with a billing plan amount of 100,000 GBP. The project is assigned to a company code that uses EUR as company code currency.

Figure 1: comparison SPFC - SPFCFX

Both EBRR keys start by using the exchange rate valid at the beginning of the first posting period ‚Äì 1:1. However, differences become noticeable in period 5. The SPFC key, which uses a frozen rate, determines the exchange rate based on the billing WBS element‚Äôs creation date ‚Äì 1:1. In contrast, the new key applies the exchange rate from the first day of the current posting period ‚Äì 1:1,3. Thus, in period 5 for the recognized revenue of the period, 10.000 ¬£, the new key uses the current exchange rate of 1:1.3. This results in realized revenue and WIP of 13.000 ‚Ç¨‚Äîcompared to 10.000 ‚Ç¨ realized with the SPFC key.

The new key does not revalue the WIP from previous periods‚Äî in our example, the WIP of 10.000 ‚Ç¨ in period 1 remains unchanged. The current exchange rate of 1:1.3 is applied only to the realized revenue and WIP in period 5. This approach aligns with IFRS and US GAAP requirements.

To revalue the entire WIP using the current rate, the Advanced Foreign Currency Valuation (AFCV) could be applied.

Figure 2 : AFCV (advanced foreign currency run)

Features and Principles of the New Revenue Recognition and Currency Method

The new Event-Based Revenue Recognition (EBRR) method and its currency handling bring significant changes in how revenue is recognized and translated. Here‚Äôs an overview of the key features:

Generally, the project currency is used as transaction currency in ACDOCA for the EBRR postings.

Percentage of Completion Calculated in Company Code Currency

The Percentage of Completion (POC) is calculated in the company code currency. This resulting percentage is then applied to the transaction currency to determine the recognized revenue.

  • Actuals are derived from ACDOCA journal entries.
  • The determination of plan and EAC costs in company code currency depends on the plan source. For example, when reading CPM resource plan costs (source 305), the plan costs are converted using the exchange rate of the respective period.

Consistent Currency Translation Date Within the Reporting Period

For EBRR, the currency conversion date is set to the first day of the reporting period. This ensures that realized revenue is consistent and comparable within the same period.

All EBRR journal entries‚Äîwhether posted in real time or during the period-end run‚Äîuse this date as the exchange rate reference.

General ledger postings such as billing continue to use a daily (M) exchange rate. 

Handling Currency Effects and Valuation of Work in Progress (WIP)

Currency effects arise from the difference between realized and billed revenue. These effects are explicitly shown and posted only at period-end when deferred and accrued (WIP) amounts need to be netted. WIP netting is performed using the FIFO method.

  •             With this we ensure that the remaining WIP is valuated with most current currency rate. 

For updating WIP with current rate use AFCV

Since only the revenue realized in the period is translated using the current rate, the WIP from previous periods needs to be revalued through AFCV. 

Solution approach

With the 2508 release, SAP introduces important enhancements for revenue recognition in fixed price customer projects using cost-based percentage of completion (POC). 

A new revenue recognition key, SPFCFX, is now available. This key uses revenue recognition method 25, which is linked to foreign currency method 28. The key feature of this method is that the currency logic is hardcoded and cannot be adjusted. As a result, the standard foreign currency method (typically left blank or ‚Äòspace‚Äô) defined at company code level is ignored when using SPFCFX. 

In addition, a new SSCUI has been introduced to extend the scope for selecting plan sources. For the new currency method, by default, plan source 305 is delivered. 

Another innovation in this release: for the first time, it's possible to work with manual plan data in CPM projects. This opens new flexibility for customers who prefer to manage planning manually rather than relying solely on system-generated data. The following example illustrates how the new manual plan source can be used in practice. 

This new currency method in EBRR is not applicable to other methods like Completed Contract, Periodic Revenue Recognition, or Time and Expense Billing.

 

2. System walkthrough with new rev rec key 

Now, let‚Äôs look in the system at how the new revenue recognition impacts EBRR calculation and journal entries.

We have chosen a simple example to keep the focus on explaining the new foreign currency method.

In our example, the project currency is GBP, the company code currency is EUR, and the global currency is USD. Throughout this blog series, we will take a closer look at the currency conversion from GBP to EUR, and the procedure shown can then be applied to global currency scenarios as well.

Plan source 500 is assigned to the project, which means that plan data must be uploaded manually.

How to upload plan data ‚Äî and how changes to that plan data interact with the new foreign currency method ‚Äî will be explained in Section 4 of this blog.

Figure 3 : CPM Project in foreign currency

For the manually uploaded plan data, an initial exchange rate of 1:1 was maintained. The plan data is converted using the exchange rate maintained under exchange rate type ‚ÄòP‚Äô. Below is a snapshot of the exchange rates applicable in May:

Figure 4 : Currency exchange rates type 'P''

For this project, costs of 10,000 GBP, converted to 10.000‚Ç¨ and revenue of 12,000 GBP were uploaded as plan data. The transaction currency corresponds to the project‚Äôs currency, so no conversion in EBRR is needed for the plan revenues ‚Äì 12,000GBP are taken. For the POC calculation EBRR will take the 10.000‚Ç¨ as plan costs/EAC.

Figure 5 : Project Plan/Actuals

In the next step, the planned Platinum Consultant from Service Organization 1010 posts time to the project. 10 hours were recorded at a cost rate of 100 EUR/hour, resulting in costs of 1.000 EUR. This results in a POC of 10%. The POC of 10% is multiplied with the planned revenue of 12,000 GBP, to get realized revenue of 1,200 GBP.

Figure 6 : Exchange rates type 'M' for May

To analyze the posted currency amounts in detail, we use the ‚ÄòDisplay Line Items ‚Äì Margin Analysis‚Äô report.

Figure 7: first time confirmation in May

In these journal entry items the initial 1:1 exchange rate is reflected.

We have also included the object currency in the report. As you can see, the object currency is aligned with the project currency (GBP). The object currency plays an important role in the new functionality, as it ensures a consistent currency is used for costs, EBRR postings and revenue throughout the process. It also serves as the basis for calculation during period-end closing. We‚Äôll come back to this point later in the blog.

In the EBRR period-end closing for May no adjustments are posted. So, we move on to the next step:

A second time confirmation for June, along with the creation of the first customer invoice. Both the time confirmation and the billing are executed on the same day ‚Äì June 17.

However, these transactions will generate postings with different exchange rates, depending on the currencies involved and the timing of each posting.

Therefore, we‚Äôll start with an overview of the exchange rates used.

Figure 8 : Exchange rates type 'M' for June

Again, the consultant reports 10 hours, and the planned data, cost rate, and price remain unchanged. Therefore, the same POC is calculated as with the first-time recording.

However, due to the way exchange rates are maintained, different exchange rates are applied to each posting, here‚Äôs how it looks in the system.

Figure 9 : second time confirmation in June

The new currency conversion method uses the first day of the posting period as the exchange rate date for converting GBP to EUR; on June 1st, the exchange rate was maintained at 1:1,1. This time, the revenue value differs due to the exchange rate applied, resulting in a value of 1.320 EUR.

In the object currency of the cost posting, the usage of the monthly 'M' rate can be observed: the cost posted in EUR with 1.000‚Ç¨ is converted by 1:1,1 to 909,09 GBP.

The next step is to execute the first billing for the project. It was agreed that an amount of 1,500 GBP should be invoiced on June 17. The created journal entries we analyze here:

Figure 10 : Billing in June

The invoice uses the invoice date to determine the exchange rate and applies the daily 'M' rate, which results in 1,500 GBP * 1,2 = 1.800 EUR.

We‚Äôre moving into period-end closing. Accrued revenue is higher than deferred, and postings were made with different exchange rates ‚Äî something to keep in mind.

Here‚Äôs a snapshot of what‚Äôs been booked so far:

Figure 11: G/L account posting overview

The period-end closing still nets the balance sheet accounts as before ‚Äî but now it also calculates currency effects based on the exchange rate differences.

Here‚Äôs what the closing entries look like this time:

Figure 12 : EBRR period end June with currency effect

You can see that the deferred revenue account was cleared, there was a WIP reduction, and a separate posting for currency effects was created.

Let‚Äôs break it down:

  • There‚Äôs an invoice for 1,500 GBP.
  • Two-time recordings exist:
  • 1,200 GBP from May
  • 1,200 GBP from June
    ‚Üí Total time recorded: 2,400 GBP

Since time recorded exceeds the invoice amount, we can reduce deferred revenue by reducing accrued revenue (WIP).

The reduction now follows the FIFO principle ‚Äì first in, first out.

  1. The May time entry (1,200 GBP) was booked at a 1:1 exchange rate.
    ‚Üí This full amount is used: 1,200 GBP ‚Üí 1.200 EUR
  1. That leaves 300 GBP to be covered.
    This comes from the June time entry, booked at a 1:1,1 rate.
    ‚Üí 300 GBP ‚Üí 330 EUR

This leads to a WIP reduction of 1,500 GBP, calculated as 1.200 EUR (from the first-time entry) plus 330 EUR (from the second) ‚Äî totaling 1.530 EUR.

Now, currency effects are calculated at Company Code currency level:

  • Deferred revenue: 1.800 EUR
  • Accrued revenue: 1.530 EUR
  • Currency effect: 270 EUR

The currency effect is posted using a dedicated SLALI-type 8201. This ensures full transparency ‚Äî allowing you to report on currency effects at any time.

The same logic is applied in Group Currency ‚Äî based on the respective exchange rates used in the original postings.

Another important aspect to understand is how the new functionality behaves when the status ‚ÄòCompleted‚Äô (TECO) is set before all WIP is cleared.

In our case, that‚Äôs 900 GBP, which corresponds to 990 EUR and 1,188 USD.

The ‚ÄòCompleted‚Äô status is set on July 29, which means the period-end closing for July must be executed to automatically release all remaining WIP.

And this is what the postings look like:

Figure 13 : EBRR period end July / posting date view

At first glance, nothing seems unusual ‚Äî the system posts one line to accrued revenue and another to the revenue adjustment account.

What‚Äôs new, however, is that it's now much more meaningful to view the postings from an account perspective at the project level.

Figure 14 : EBRR period end July- G/L account view

In the overview, you can see that currency effects are not reversed when the project is completed.

Previously, once a project was completed, the billed revenue reflected the total revenue earned from the project. That was the full story.

With the new currency handling exchange rate differences are now recognized separately on the currency effect account.

As a result, it‚Äôs no longer enough to look at billed revenue alone. To get the full revenue picture, you now need to combine billed revenue and revenue adjustment, offset by the amount on the currency effects account.

 

3. EBRR revenue recognition at period-end in specific situations

The period-end closing with the new key now delivers the currency effects. Here‚Äôs a first look at the behavior when the currency method is activated.

For all revenue recognition methods, Event-Based Revenue Recognition (EBRR) uses a principal currency for period-end closing activities. The principal currency is the reference currency used during the re-evaluation of EBRR at period-end. Re-evaluation is performed either automatically during the period-end closing run or manually for a specific WBS billing element. Its purpose is to adjust revenue recognition based on updated data, net balance sheet accounts, and‚Äîif necessary‚Äîrecalculate the entire object, for example due to changes in plan.

For the new EBRR key, the object currency is used as the principal currency. In project-based scenarios, this corresponds to the project currency.

What differentiates the new approach from the Currency Method SPACE in the existing key SPFC is that, during period-end closing, both the company code currency and the global currency are translated.

As a result, no currency effects are calculated in the transaction currency. The value in transaction currency always corresponds to the current percentage of completion (POC) multiplied by the planned revenue in the object currency. Currency effects are recognized in both the company code currency and the global currency.

It is also important to understand that the EBRR period-end calculation does not re-evaluate the posted WIP or realized revenue using the current exchange rate; this revaluation can instead be performed using AFCV.

In our example, we have seen two situations; WIP exceeding deferred revenue and TECO set with remaining WIP. These are just two of several possible cases. 

There are additional rules the currency method follows, depending on the situation.

Let‚Äôs look at how the system behaves in other posting scenarios. 

To better understand this, let‚Äôs briefly recap the general logic of period-end closing ‚Äî independent of the currency method. Period-end closing reads all actual costs and revenues posted to the billing or cost WBS element, along with the relevant plan data. Based on this, the system calculates the current POC, which is then used to determine the updated WIP and realized revenue.

POC change caused by new EAC calculation

Even if there are no actual postings added, a new POC may be calculated based on adjusted plan/ EAC data, which leads to a revised recognized revenue.

One reason could be a currency effect in EAC calculation. This can especially happen, if you use plan source 305 or 306. In the CPM application, resource/ cost planning is always done in project/object currency. For source 305 and 306, the planned costs need to be converted into Company Code currency to calculate POC. This conversion also uses the 'M' exchange rate from the first day of the posting period.

Using plan source 303, there could be a new updated baseline. For source 500 you could use new updated plan data.

The system reacts the following:

  • If there is additional revenue recognized, it is translated into company code and global currency with
    •  the rate of the period if no open WIP at period end exists.
    • If WIP exists, the revenue is translated with the historic (average) WIP rate
    • If there is a revenue deduction calculated it is translated with the FIFO rate

If the result is that accrued revenue exceeds deferred revenue, a few things need to be considered ‚Äî in addition to the posting behavior already shown in the system example.

  • A new POC is calculated based on current actuals and plan data, which can lead to a revised recognized revenue:

The period end process nets accrued and deferred revenue, adjusts recognized revenue accordingly, and calculates currency effects. Recognized revenue is posted using the historic (average) rate of the WIP.

  • If a TECO status is set and POC is changed, a revaluation is triggered using the average exchange rate of the open WIP at that time.

Background: According to IAS 21, revenue must be recognized using the spot exchange rate at the time the service is performed. When a project is set to TECO and revenue has been earned across multiple periods, a single exchange rate is not sufficient. Instead, an average rate based on the remaining open WIP is calculated to reflect the blended spot rates over time. 

Another possible outcome is that deferred revenue exceeds accrued revenue.

Let‚Äôs walk through a simple example to illustrate how currency effects can arise during period-end closing.

Step 1: Initial cost posting in June

In June, there is a time confirmation of 10 hours, posted at an exchange rate of 1:1,1 (GBP to EUR). This results in:

  • ¬£1,200 in the transaction currency (GBP)
  • ‚Ç¨1.320 in the company code currency (EUR)

Figure 15: Initial cost posting June

 

 

 

Step 2. Billing 

Two invoices are posted in June:

  • On June 17, an invoice for ¬£1,000 / ‚Ç¨1.200 at an exchange rate of 1.2
  • On June 18, an invoice for ¬£1,500 / ‚Ç¨1.950 at an exchange rate of 1.3

Figure 16 : Step 2 : Billing

With this, a weighted average exchange rate is derived for the deferred revenue:

  • ‚Ç¨3.150 / ¬£2,500 = 1,26

Step 3: EBRR Period end

At period-end, the deferrals are netted using this weighted average rate.

Figure 17 : EBRR Period end June

  • The system clears ¬£1,200 from deferred revenue.
  • Using the weighted rate of 1,26, this corresponds to ‚Ç¨1.512 (1.200 * 1.26).

 Step 4: Calculating Currency Effects

However, only ‚Ç¨1,320 was recognized as WIP earlier (based on the original rate of 1,1).

This results in a currency effect of ‚Ç¨192:

  • ‚Ç¨1,512 (clearing) ‚Äì ‚Ç¨1.320 (WIP) = ‚Ç¨192 currency difference

The status is set to Completed (TECO) when deferred revenue exceeds accrued revenue, which is another possible scenario.

This situation can also lead to currency effects during period-end processing.

  • The period end process identifies recognized revenue and open WIP that has not yet been invoiced
  • Compute an average WIP exchange rate based on the open WIP items. This rate represents a weighted average of the spot rates applicable at the time each portion of the WIP was earned.
  • Use the calculated average rate to convert the revenue from the transaction currency to the company code currency. This ensures revenue is recognized appropriately in line with the actual earning periods

 Background: According to IAS 21, revenue must be recognized using the spot       exchange rate at the time the service is performed. When a project is set to TECO   and revenue has been earned across multiple periods, a single exchange rate is  not sufficient. Instead, an average rate based on the remaining open WIP is calculated to reflect the blended spot rates over time. 

  • The remaining open WIP can be fully cleared

Down payment

Fixed price projects continue to be supported by the down payment process. The new currency method has no impact on down payment handling. The established posting logic remains unchanged. This includes the netting of the down payment contract liability with a possible WIP balance. 

What is new in this context is that the netting now receives its own SLALI-Type.: 08103 Accrued Revenue Adjustment by Down Payment Liability Clearing. This change allows the currency method to identify and exclude netting lines from currency conversion logic.

 

4.    Control in event-based revenue recognition 

To enable the functionality described above, the key SPFCFX has been delivered.

This key uses the new revenue recognition method 25, which uses cost-based POC based on company code currency and uses the new currency logic. It is hardcoded linked to currency method 28. Using the currency method, currency effects are calculated and WIP is reduced based on FIFO.

Figure 18 : EBRR Key SPFCFX

For this new key, it is now possible to choose between four different plan sources ‚Äì a functionality that is also new and delivered with release 2508.

There is now an SSC UI available in EBRR configuration that allows you to assign the supported plan sources to the new key.

As part of the new currency method rollout, manual plan data is now supported, source 500, ‚Äî as shown in the system example.

In addition, the new key is also supported by plan sources 303, 305, and 306.

Sources 305 and 306 are specifically used for CPM projects and are integrated via the Review Customer Projects App, which allows to manually adjust EAC and POC. This planning data is considered by EBRR, independent of the used cost-based POC method.

Before we get into the SSC UI, let‚Äôs start with a brief overview of the plan data and what it means in the context of revenue recognition.

  • 303: Here we take the plan costs from ACDOCP, which are updated by CPM baseline (baseline plan category).  Plan costs exist in transaction, company, and global currency. Currency conversion takes place once during baseline creation or when the baseline is updated. With this POC effects from exchange rates changes are avoided. The planned revenue is based on CPM/SD billing plan. These planned data are used in real-time and period-end processing.
  • 305 (Default): Plan costs from CPM resource planning converted to company code currency with 'M' of the current period‚ÄìPlan revenues from CPM/SD billing plan. If there are manual adjustments made in the Review Customer Project, the review app plan data are considered.
  • 306: Real-time: Same as 305 ‚Äì plan costs from CPM, plan revenues from CPM/SD billing plan. The period end run uses the actual estimation (EAC) from the Review Customer Project App, while planned revenue is derived from the CPM/SD billing plan. This may lead to POC adjustments.
  • 500: Plan costs and revenues from ACDOCP, based on manual plan category.
    Used in real-time and period-end.

The existing SSCUI now allows assignment of a plan source.

Figure 19: Source of plan values - overview

The following sources can be selected via the F4 help:

Figure 20 : Plan sources details

For the first time, this release introduces the possibility to work with manual plan data in CPM projects. If you want to use the manual version, you first need to set it up in the 'Maintain Category for Planning' app.

Figure 21 : manual plan category for projects

With the assignment of application type ‚ÄúProject Management‚Äù additional checks and derivation logic are provided by the plan update.

A WBS element must be provided for every planning line item. This prevents an accidental deletion of planned data provided for other projects, which can happen when you use a periodic plan category like PLN.

The account assignment type ‚ÄúWBS element‚Äú is determined for all planning line items and additional attributes are taken from the project and assigned sales order item like profit center or margin analysis fields are derived and stored for the planning line items.

The 'Import Financial Plan Data' app is required to upload plan data. The app provides an option to download a template for project planning.

Figure 22 : Import manual plan data

After uploading, the data can be viewed.

Figure 23: Display uploaded manual plan data

5.    EBRR key change for a WBS billing element

The change of the EBRR key from the previously used key SPFC to the new one is supported and enables future postings to follow the updated currency method.

There are, however, a few general aspects to consider when making this change.

  • Recognized Revenues already posted will not be recalculated retrospectively .
  • New calculated recognized revenue with key SPFCX will be translated with the currency rate of the current period ‚Äì even if the confirmation was posted in previous periods.
  • Different options are available for executing the change (see next figure 24).
  • The remaining duration of the project should be considered when deciding on the appropriate approach.
  • For transparency reasons if you directly change to new key it is recommended to keep the plan source the same. If you change indirectly with intermediate steps in between as shown in figure 25, you could change the plan source
  • Restriction: At the time of transition, no open Contract Liabilities for down payments must exist. If open Contract Liabilities are present, the currency effect calculation will not work correctly.

First, an overview of the key differences between the keys:

Figure 24 : Differences SPFC - SPFCFX

Switching from an existing revenue recognition key to the new EBRR key could be performed with two options, both following a two-step process within the same posting period.

Option 1: Temporary Switch via 'non Rev Rec' Key

  1. Replace the current revenue recognition key with a 'non Rev Rec' key.
  2. Run the first period-end closing using the 'non Rev Rec' key to clear existing balances without triggering revenue recognition.
  3. Update the key to the new EBRR key.
  4. Run the period-end closing again for the same period using the new key.

Option 2: TECO and Reopen Approach

  1. Set the project to Completed (TECO) status.
  2. Run the period-end closing with the existing revenue recognition key to finalize the old logic.
  3. Reopen the project by resetting the status.
  4. Assign the new EBRR key.
  5. Execute a second period-end closing for the same period using the new key.

Figure 25 : EBRR Key change

 1 With SPFC, the global currency is not handled by EBRR at all ‚Äì it is always calculated by RWIN. Any balance in global currency is only processed at TECO.

After switching to SPFCX, however, the global currency (as well as all other currencies) is now handled by EBRR.

Remark: the direct change to SPFCX is not recommended as there will be EBRR data, which does not align with new method ‚Äì e.g. transaction currency not in project currency. New features like currency effects, are not fully supported in a direct switch from SPFC to SPFCFX, remaining potential WIP from SPFC process is reduced as posted, using the frozen rate. . Global currency of already posted EBRR journal entries are translated by RWIN and not EBRR.

 Closing remarks

We hope you enjoyed this new EBBR functionality for customer projects in S/4HANA public cloud. It is another scenario, in which we are now benefiting from the innovations in financial accounting.

Feedback welcome

entry.title: Re: Using Integration Center and/or Intelligent Services Centre to update Background Elements or MDF
entry.content:

entry.title: How I Fixed ‚Äúnon-fast-forward‚Äù and ‚Äúunrelated histories‚Äù Git Errors ‚Äì Real-World Debugging
entry.content:
Overview of My Issue:

While working on a Bitbucket hosted SAP UI5 project, I tried to push my local changes to the remote development branch as my first commit using: git push origin development

 

Screenshot 1.1: Non-Fast-Forward Error

Because, my current branch is behind the remote and git is preventing me from accidentally overwriting changes.

To fix this, I attempted to pull the latest changes from the remote branch: git pull origin development

Again i received the fatal: refusing to merge unrelated histories error as below:

Screenshot 1.2: Refusing to merge unrelated histories

This is because my local and remote repositories had no shared commit history.

 

Steps I followed to resolve the issue

Here's how I resolved the issue in a few steps:

Step 1: Allow Merging Unrelated Histories

git pull origin development --allow-unrelated-histories

This command tells git to merge two separate project histories, even if they‚Äôre not connected. It's usually needed when:

‚Ä¢ You created a local repository using  git init before linking it to a remote one

‚Ä¢ The remote repository already has some commits, like a README or .gitignore file

Screenshot 1.3: Running the --allow-unrelated-histories command

 

Step 2: Resolve Merge Conflicts (If Any)

Git may pause and ask us to resolve merge conflicts. Open the files, resolve the changes, and then run following commands:

git add .

git commit -m "Merged unrelated histories"

Screenshot 1.4: Merge unrelated histories

 

Step 3: Push Successfully

Once everything was committed, I finally ran:

git push origin development

And it worked! My changes were safely pushed to the remote branch.

Here you can see the actual bitbucket commit section for better understanding

 

Why This Happens

This is common when:

  • When we created a local repo without cloning the remote first
  • The remote repo already had commits we don‚Äôt have locally
  • Histories diverge and git can't auto-resolve them

Instead of force-pushing and risking overwrite, Git stops us and let's merge safely.

 

Take away points:

  • Never force push (--force) unless we are sure that we are not overwriting someone else‚Äôs work.
  • Use git log --oneline --graph to understand commit history visually.
  • Always pull before push. Keeps your repo safe from conflicts.

Git errors can be confusing at first glance, but once we understand the intent behind them, they actually protect our code.

If you're working with SAP UI5, Fiori or any frontend Git workflow. This is a handy fix to remember.

Thank you for taking the time to read this blog! Please suggest your way of approach!

If you found this helpful, feel free to share your thoughts, feedback or questions in the comments! Let's keep learning and growing together. Happy coding!

entry.title: Re: Integration Suite and Connection Type G for synchronous BAPIs?
entry.content: The BD97 is used to configure the RFC Destinations for ALE Scenarios based on distribution models. If you are calling individually an remote BAPI (e.g. Call Function 'xxxx' destination 'yyyy') than you don't need BD97. There are various sychronization scenarios using BD64 to be configured where you configure here as destination the logical system only. This needs to be tied via BD97 to an Destination (similarly like WE20 for IDOC). If both systems are not in the same network, maybe a shared gateway service could help. If both systems still belongs to the same company, SAP Basis could maybe allow you to connect to Solution Manager's Gateway service that can be reached from both Backend System.

entry.title: Advanced ATP Product Allocation (PAL) integration: SAP IBP to S/4HANA
entry.content:
Advanced ATP Product Allocation (PAL) integration: SAP IBP to S/4HANA

In Advanced ATP (aATP), one of the key functionalities is Product Allocation (PAL), which ensures the fair distribution of a limited supply based on specific business-defined parameters, such as customer or region.

In an integrated SAP IBP‚ÄìS/4HANA setup, allocation planning occurs in IBP, while allocation consumption and checks take place on the S/4 side. That‚Äôs the reason transferring PAL data from IBP to S4HANA is important.

 During my project requirement, I was involved in building this interface in the client system, and based on the same experience, I captured the functional side of developing the interface between IBP and S4. Also, I documented the issues I faced in the 'Factors to be considered' section of the blog. 

Business Scenario:

Let‚Äôs take an example from the automotive industry, managing constrained components like EV batteries has become a critical supply chain priority. Original Equipment Manufacturers (OEMs) must ensure that these limited parts are allocated to dealerships‚Äîoften across global regions‚Äîwithout disturbing customer commitments.

SAP IBP is typically used to plan product allocations at a granular level (e.g., Product + Plant + Customer Group) based on forecasted demand and capacity constraints. However, the actual order fulfilment and availability checks occur in SAP S/4HANA using Advanced ATP (AATP)- Product Availability Check (PAC) functionality.

To ensure real-time synchronization between planning and execution, it becomes essential to transfer PAL data from IBP to S/4HANA, where AATP can enforce allocation limits during sales order creation.

I have created a PAL object in S/4HANA based on the following characteristics, like Customer Group, Plant, and Material Number.

An automotive OEM manufactures electric vehicles across three global plants. Due to a global shortage of lithium-ion battery packs:

  • Allocation planning is done in IBP, assigning weekly quantities of battery packs to each plant and customer group (e.g., retail, Government accounts, etc.).
  • These allocation limits are exported from IBP and pushed to S/4HANA using the SAP standard API API_PRODUCT_ALLOCATION_OBJECT_SRV.
  • When dealers place new vehicle orders, AATP PAC checks the current PAL object to determine whether the battery supply is still available for that period and the customer group and Plant combination.
  • If allocation is exhausted, the order is rescheduled, split, or denied based on AATP logic.

     

Solution approach: Mostly, the solution design covers the following points

  • Pre-requisites:
  1. PAL functionality should be activated in the system. (Please refer to the SAP Help portal for more information: Reference section)
  2. The PAL object should be configured in the system, and the FIORI configuration should be completed.
  3. Finite Heuristic Solve should be completed in SAP IBP, and a Constrained Supply Plan should be generated.

     Step-by-step Solution approach: 

            1. PAL Data Extraction from IBP

  •  Time-series-based PAL data is maintained in SAP IBP using planning operators or manual input.
  •  Data can be extracted via OData API (e.g., using SAP CPI).
  • The extract contains fields like Product, Location, Date, Allocation Quantity, and CVC attributes (e.g., Customer Group).

             2. Transformation Layer (SAP CPI)

  • Transform IBP field names and structures to match the input structure of API_PRODUCT_ALLOCATION_OBJECT_SRV.
  • Based on the business requirement, convert the time bucket values, like weekly/monthly buckets from IBP are converted to daily values, as required by S/4.

             3. API-Based Upload to S/4HANA

        Use the OData service API_PRODUCT_ALLOCATION_OBJECT_SRV. 

  1. Create or update Product Allocation Object headers (A_ProductAllocationObject)
  2. Create associated items (A_ProductAllocationObjectItem) for characteristics.
  3. Upload time-series allocations (A_ProductAllocationTimeSeries)

          4. Validation & Error Handling

            Errors such as:  Invalid Master Data (e.g., Product) in S4 and Missing Characteristics. 

 

Factors to be considered:

Based on my recent Project experience during the development of this interface, I faced a couple of issues, which I tried to capture as follows:

As this solution requires proper alignment between SAP IBP and OTC, smooth and timely coordination is the key factor between the two teams to achieve the desired results

                1.   Alignment of Planning and Consumption Time Buckets

  • IBP typically uses weekly time buckets.
  • S/4HANA AATP may expect monthly PAL buckets (time series per month).
  •  Use CPI or ABAP logic to merge weekly allocations into monthly values, as required.

               2. Characteristic Value Combinations (CVCs)

  • IBP can plan at aggregated levels like Product/Location/Customer Group.
  • PAL in S/4 needs exact matching characteristics, e.g., Product + Plant + Customer Group.
  • All characteristics in S/4 must be available as fields in the PAL object.
  • Mismatch in CVCs causes API rejection. 
  • During the selection of CVCs, we should consider the volume of data load in S/4 to avoid any performance issues. 

               3. API Volume and Performance

  • Use batch calls in the OData API for bulk data uploads. SAP Note 3042321 offers performance tips. (Check the Reference section: G)

               4. Misc. Considerations

  • Overwriting Existing Allocations? Define logic for overwrite vs. append. Consider this a critical one. 
  • Emergency Allocation Changes? How will last-minute changes be pushed (manual vs. automated)? Business has to align with the same. 
  • PAL and Backorder Processing (BOP): Ensure PAL object updates align with scheduled BOP runs.
  • How to handle obsolete PAL objects in S/4 (Archival vs. Deletion)? Check with the business team on how to handle this post-go-live scenario when the system will have a large number of PAL objects down the line. 
  • Check with the business regarding the volume of transactions beforehand to avoid any last-minute surprises.

               5. Notification System

  • Send email/SAP alert for: Repeated failures, Bulk upload errors, etc. 

Conclusion:

Integrating SAP IBP with S/4HANA for Product Allocation (PAL) is a critical step toward enabling intelligent, constraint-based order promising through AATP. By leveraging the SAP standard OData API, an organization can automate and streamline the transfer of allocation quantities and characteristic combinations. The end success depends on the testing part with the business team in the non-production environment. 

Please share your questions, comments, and feedback.

References:

  1. IBP Interaction with aATP ‚Äì Transfer of Product Allocation Data
  2. General & performance recommendations for "Manage Product Allocation Planning Data" - App with a huge no. of CVCs / API_PRODUCT_ALLOCATION_OBJECT_SRV
  3. https://api.sap.com/api/API_PRODUCT_ALLOCATION_OBJECT_SRV/overview
  4. Product Allocation (CA-ATP-PAL) | SAP Help Portal
